functions.def: function safeTransferFrom(address _from, address _to, uint256 _id, uint256 _value, bytes calldata _data) external

throw.if: balance of holder for token `_id` is lower than the `_value` sent
`_to` is a smart contract (e.g. code size > 0)
Caller must be approved to manage the tokens being transferred out of the `_from` account

emit.if: the balance change is reflected after the transfer

call.if: _to is a smart contract (e.g. code size > 0)

arg_rules.rule: _data MUST be sent unaltered

functions.def: function safeBatchTransferFrom(address _from, address _to, uint256[] calldata _ids, uint256[] calldata _values, bytes calldata _data) external

throw.if: length of `_ids` is not the same as length of `_values`
any of the balance(s) of the holder(s) for token(s) in `_ids` is lower than the respective amount(s) in `_values` sent to the recipient
`_to` is a smart contract (e.g. code size > 0)
caller must be approved to manage the tokens being transferred out of the `_from` account

emit.if: all the balance changes are reflected and the transfer conditions are met

call.if: `_to` is a smart contract (e.g. code size > 0)

arg_rules.rule: `_data` MUST be sent unaltered in call to the `ERC1155TokenReceiver` hook(s) on `_to`

functions.def: function balanceOf(address _owner, uint256 _id) external view returns (uint256)

extracted.semantic_return: The return value of the function `balanceOf(address _owner, uint256 _id)` represents the quantity of tokens of a specific type (identified by `_id`) that are currently held by a particular account (specified by `_owner`). This function provides a way to check how many tokens of a certain type an account possesses at the time the function is called.

extract_debug.semantic_return: The return value of the function `balanceOf(address _owner, uint256 _id)` represents the quantity of tokens of a specific type (identified by `_id`) that are currently held by a particular account (specified by `_owner`). This function provides a way to check how many tokens of a certain type an account possesses at the time the function is called.

functions.def: function balanceOfBatch(address[] calldata _owners, uint256[] calldata _ids) external view returns (uint256[] memory)

extracted.semantic_return:
The return value of the function `balanceOfBatch(address[] calldata _owners, uint256[] calldata _ids)` is an array of unsigned integers (`uint256[]`). Each element in this returned array represents the balance of a specific token held by a specific owner. The function takes two arrays as inputs: `_owners`, which contains the addresses of the token holders, and `_ids`, which contains the IDs of the tokens. The function returns the balances corresponding to each pair of owner and token ID provided in the input arrays.

For example, if the input arrays are `_owners = [address1, address2]` and `_ids = [token1, token2]`, the function will return an array where the first element is the balance of `token1` held by `address1`, the second element is the balance of `token2` held by `address1`, the third element is the balance of `token1` held by `address2`, and the fourth element is the balance of `token2` held by `address2`. Thus, the function systematically returns the balances for each combination of the provided owner addresses and token IDs.

Thus, the function systematically returns the balances for each combination of the provided owner addresses and token IDs.

functions.def: function isApprovedForAll(address _owner, address _operator) external view returns (bool)

extracted.semantic_return: The function `isApprovedForAll(address _owner, address _operator)` returns a boolean value that indicates whether the specified `_operator` address is authorized to manage all tokens owned by the `_owner` address. If the function returns `true`, it means that the `_operator` is approved to handle all tokens of the `_owner`. Conversely, if it returns `false`, the `_operator` does not have approval to manage the tokens of `_owner`.

extract_debug.semantic_return: The function `isApprovedForAll(address _owner, address _operator)` returns a boolean value that indicates whether the specified `_operator` address is authorized to manage all tokens owned by the `_owner` address. If the function returns `true`, it means that the `_operator` is approved to handle all tokens of the `_owner`. Conversely, if it returns `false`, the `_operator` does not have approval to manage the tokens of `_owner`.

events.def: event TransferSingle(address indexed _operator, address indexed _from, address indexed _to, uint256 _id, uint256 _value);
events.raw_rules:
/**
        @dev Either `TransferSingle` or `TransferBatch` MUST emit when tokens are transferred, including zero value transfers as well as minting or burning (see "Safe Transfer Rules" section of the standard).
        The `_operator` argument MUST be the address of an account/contract that is approved to make the transfer (SHOULD be msg.sender).
        The `_from` argument MUST be the address of the holder whose balance is decreased.
        The `_to` argument MUST be the address of the recipient whose balance is increased.
        The `_id` argument MUST be the token type being transferred.
        The `_value` argument MUST be the number of tokens the holder balance is decreased by and match what the recipient balance is increased by.
        When minting/creating tokens, the `_from` argument MUST be set to `0x0` (i.e. zero address).
        When burning/destroying tokens, the `_to` argument MUST be set to `0x0` (i.e. zero address).        
    */

emit.if: tokens are transferred, including zero value transfers as well as minting or burning

arg_rules.rule: MUST be the address of an account/contract that is approved to make the transfer (SHOULD be msg.sender)
MUST be the address of the holder whose balance is decreased
MUST be the address of the recipient whose balance is increased
MUST be the token type being transferred
MUST be the number of tokens the holder balance is decreased by and match what the recipient balance is increased by
MUST be set to `0x0` (i.e. zero address)
MUST be set to `0x0` (i.e. zero address)

extract_debug.assign:
```json
[
    "The `_from` argument MUST be set to `0x0` when minting/creating tokens",
    "The `_to` argument MUST be set to `0x0` when burning/destroying tokens"
]
```

events.def: event TransferBatch(address indexed _operator, address indexed _from, address indexed _to, uint256[] _ids, uint256[] _values);
events.raw_rules:
/**
        @dev Either `TransferSingle` or `TransferBatch` MUST emit when tokens are transferred, including zero value transfers as well as minting or burning (see "Safe Transfer Rules" section of the standard).      
        The `_operator` argument MUST be the address of an account/contract that is approved to make the transfer (SHOULD be msg.sender).
        The `_from` argument MUST be the address of the holder whose balance is decreased.
        The `_to` argument MUST be the address of the recipient whose balance is increased.
        The `_ids` argument MUST be the list of tokens being transferred.
        The `_values` argument MUST be the list of number of tokens (matching the list and order of tokens specified in _ids) the holder balance is decreased by and match what the recipient balance is increased by.
        When minting/creating tokens, the `_from` argument MUST be set to `0x0` (i.e. zero address).
        When burning/destroying tokens, the `_to` argument MUST be set to `0x0` (i.e. zero address).                
    */

emit.if: tokens are transferred, including zero value transfers as well as minting or burning

arg_rules.rule: MUST be the address of an account/contract that is approved to make the transfer (SHOULD be msg.sender)
MUST be the address of the holder whose balance is decreased
MUST be the address of the recipient whose balance is increased
MUST be the list of tokens being transferred
MUST be the list of number of tokens (matching the list and order of tokens specified in _ids) the holder balance is decreased by and match what the recipient balance is increased by
MUST be set to `0x0` (i.e. zero address)
MUST be set to `0x0` (i.e. zero address)

events.def: event ApprovalForAll(address indexed _owner, address indexed _operator, bool _approved);

emit.if: approval for a second party/operator address to manage all tokens for an owner address is enabled or disabled
the URI is updated for a token ID

arg_rules.rule: MUST point to a JSON file that conforms to the 'ERC-1155 Metadata URI JSON Schema'
MUST be the token ID for which the URI is updated

rules.rule:
The return value of the function `balanceOfBatch(address[] calldata _owners, uint256[] calldata _ids)` is an array of unsigned integers (`uint256[]`). Each element in this returned array represents the balance of a specific token held by a specific owner. The function takes two arrays as inputs: `_owners`, which contains the addresses of the token holders, and `_ids`, which contains the IDs of the tokens. The function returns the balances corresponding to each pair of owner and token ID provided in the input arrays.

For example, if the input arrays are `_owners = [address1, address2]` and `_ids = [token1, token2]`, the function will return an array where the first element is the balance of `token1` held by `address1`, the second element is the balance of `token2` held by `address1`, the third element is the balance of `token1` held by `address2`, and the fourth element is the balance of `token2` held by `address2`. Thus, the function systematically returns the balances for each combination of the provided owner addresses and token IDs.
rules.interface: function balanceOfBatch(address[] calldata _owners, uint256[] calldata _ids) external view returns (uint256[] memory)

rules.rule: emit '['ApprovalForAll']' if on success
rules.interface: function setApprovalForAll(address _operator, bool _approved) external

rules.rule: The function `isApprovedForAll(address _owner, address _operator)` returns a boolean value that indicates whether the specified `_operator` address is authorized to manage all tokens owned by the `_owner` address. If the function returns `true`, it means that the `_operator` is approved to handle all tokens of the `_owner`. Conversely, if it returns `false`, the `_operator` does not have approval to manage the tokens of `_owner`.
